post_text:
Meet Gabriela Toro, principal of SCS Newcomer International Center!

A former student in Memphis, Toro has been with the district 17 years, the last four years she’s helped build Newcomer International Center.

"When I first started school in Memphis I was in the six grade. There were only two of us in my whole six grade class that were Hispanic. ESL back then, or English as a second language was really not thought of or it was something new,”

Watch more: https://www.wmcactionnews5.com/2020/09/15/meet-gabriela-toro-only-hispanic-principal-scs/

Thank you to WMC Action News 5 and La Prensa Latina Media for this special #HispanicHeritageMonth highlight! #SCSes901

post_text:
Despite collaborative efforts in the District and locally to reduce the spread of the Coronavirus, there is still far too much uncertainty to move forward with athletic practices and competitions at this time. Our decision to postpone contact sports until further notice is yet another unimaginable consequence of an unprecedented time. We must lean on the guidance of health experts and not emotions to keep our student-athletes safe. We want our students to play, your coaches want to coach, and we still hope for the opportunity to do both when conditions improve.

More information: http://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1316

post_text:
The Shelby County Board of Education is partnering with SchoolSeed to raise money for families with outstanding utility bills during the virtual learning period.

The SCS Board Cares Utility Assistance Fund will allow qualifying Shelby County Schools (SCS) families to receive grant money to pay MLGW bills and prevent utilities from being disconnected. The one-time grant, funded by private donations, will help prevent students from missing important virtual instruction.

“With so many families experiencing hardships due to the public health crisis, it is so important for our community to rally around our students,” said Joyce Dorse Coleman, School Board member. “Without power at home, they will certainly miss out on key instructional time.”

Learn more about the program and how to apply here:
http://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1313 #SCSis901

post_text:
Hundreds of Shelby County Schools (SCS) students received important job experiences this summer through the MPLOY VIRTUAL Summer Internship Program.

The program, made possible through a partnership between the SCS Division of College, Career, and Technical Education (CCTE) and the City of Memphis’ Office of Youth Services, provided paid internships to 1,017 SCS students at a number of Memphis-area businesses via Microsoft Teams this summer. Along with a paycheck, students earned more than 200 Work-Based Learning credits and 600 Microsoft Office and OSHA certifications.

Read more and watch Parts 2 and 3 at http://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1311

post_text: Nominations are being accepted for a lucky elementary school or schools in the Mid-South to win up to $4,000 during the sixth annual Extra Yard for Teachers Week presented by the American Athletic Conference (AAC) and DonorsChoose. Extra Yard for Teachers Week is an annual salute to teachers in recognition of their hard work and dedication. On behalf of the AAC, the Memphis Tigers are seeking nominations from all local elementary schools. Just log onto www.donorschoose.org by noon on September 15, and submit a claim or claims for resources totaling anywhere from $100 - $4,000. Be sure to reference #ExtraYardforTeachers2020 in your submission. Winners will be contacted on September 17.

We've been able to support thousands of families this week in our call center, and we're extending hours this Saturday to make sure students are all set for a successful second week of school. Call 901-416-5300 between 9 a.m. and 1 p.m. for help with student devices, Microsoft Teams, registration and enrollment, academic matters and more.

Hemos podido apoyar a miles de familias esta semana en nuestro centro de llamadas, y estamos ampliando nuestro horario este sábado para asegurarnos de que los estudiantes estén listos para una segunda semana de clases exitosa. Llame al 901-416-5300 entre las 9 a.m. y la 1 p.m. para obtener ayuda con los dispositivos de los estudiantes, Microsoft Teams, registro e inscripción, asuntos académicos y más.

post_text:
*Weekly Meals Update*

Due to the recent extension of the USDA’s Summer Meals Program, SCS is able to serve more families during the virtual learning period. This extension will also allow the District to provide bulk meals for ALL children 18 years of age and under, not just children enrolled in school, from all school locations.

Starting tomorrow Sept. 3, SCS will distribute seven-day meal packs at all school sites every Thursday. Parents can pick up meals from 9 a.m. – 12 p.m. and 1 – 5 p.m. Parents who cannot pick up on Thursdays may get their meals on Fridays, 7 – 9 a.m.

The child does not have to be present to receive meals. The Parent/guardian will need to have the student name, school and child’s birthday if they are of school age. If they are not of school age, only name and birthday are required.

Find more information at www.scsk12.org/nutrition.

post_text:
While it was an unusual start to the year, students and teachers were excited to hit the ground running. Students began the day at home in front of their new digital devices instead of in the classroom, and teachers opened their virtual classrooms greeting students using Microsoft Teams.

Over the last month, SCS has worked tirelessly to distribute a historic 95,000 digital devices and hotspots to ensure every student would be ready for the fully virtual start of the school year. As of Monday morning, approximately 90 percent of those devices have been distributed and 80 percent of SCS students had already powered up their device.

Read more: http://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1301

post_text:
We're committed to making sure every student has access to healthy meals this school year. Starting September 3, families can visit their school during designated hours every Thursday (9 a.m. - 12 p.m. & 1-5 p.m.) to get weekly meal packs. Food items will be prepared in school cafeterias and safely distributed in a drive-thru pick-up line. Parents who cannot pick up on Thursdays may get their meals on Fridays ( 7 -9 a.m.).

Learn more at http://www.scsk12.org/nutrition/.

Although we are starting virtually, we are prepared for a return to in-person education once it is safe to do so. Today, Board Members and District staff toured Brewster Elementary and Central High to see the new safety measures implemented at all schools to keep our students, staff, and educators healthy.

Learn more about safety precautions for in-person learning at scsk12.org/safeplan.

post_text:
A new daily attendance code has been established by the District and is being shared with our schools. This new attendance code (ANC - Absent for No Connection) is to be used when a student’s parent provides an excuse which indicates the student could not participate in virtual learning that day as a result of a power outage or loss of internet connectivity. As with all absences, the student is eligible for make-up work per SCS Board Policy 6014.

SCS policies and procedures are in alignment with guidance from the Tennessee Department of Education (TDOE) regarding attendance.

In addition, we are working closely with MLGW to monitor outages and disconnections, and to determine next steps around supporting families who are experiencing a disruption in service.

post_text:
Today, Superintendent Dr. Joris M. Ray published an open letter to officials with the Tennessee Secondary School Athletic Association (TSSAA) expressing concerns over frequent decisions that do not reflect the best interests of all Tennessee student-athletes.

In the letter, Dr. Ray announced the formation of an exploratory committee to evaluate SCS’ continued participation in the TSSAA. SCS is requesting immediate action and deliberation by the organization, which includes:

“In no way does our call to action mean that athletic competition has come to an end,” said Superintendent Dr. Joris M. Ray. “While the fall season has not started, conditioning will continue as previously stated. Like all athletes and coaches, ‘we want to play’ and will ensure our student-athletes have an opportunity to showcase their talents for potential post-secondary endeavors.”

Read the full letter and learn more here: http://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1298

All schools are hosting virtual orientations and open houses this week (Aug 24-28) to help families prepare for a successful start to the new school year! View the schedule at https://www.scsk12.org/virtualorientation/ for dates and times of every school's virtual event.

Families will hear from their principal about the latest school news and announcements, important dates, virtual learning schedules and details on how a variety of processes will work this year, including attendance, student meals, submitting assignments, getting support for student device, and more.

Please contact your school directly for additional questions about orientation and open house events. Find all your back to school information at scsk12.org/backtoschool. #ReturnStronger

SCS Family Forums provide an opportunity for all parents to gather, learn and share important information to support student learning and success in school. Our next Family Forum will focus on strategies and resources for students who receive support through special education, CLUE, 504 and English Language Learners. Live sessions will be led by experts from the Department of Exceptional Children and Health Services and the Department of English as a Second Language (ESL).

Join the session this Saturday, August 22 at 10 a.m. and see the schedule now at http://www.scsk12.org/familyforum.

Please submit questions to familyforum@scsk12.org.

post_text: In partnership with the City of Memphis and Shelby County Government, we are conducting a countywide Power Up Hour on Thursday, August 20 & 27 from 9 to 10 a.m. The goal is to have all virtual and in-person students and staff log onto their devices simultaneously. This will allow for internet providers to gauge capacity and respond to any challenges that may arise with that amount of traffic, so we can have a smooth and seamless experience on our first day of school and #ReturnStronger.

The Week 3 (Aug. 17-21) schedule is now live at scsk12.org/accessforall with almost 50 schools added, including our first group of elementary schools. We will be adding more schools regularly, so don't forget to check back often.

If you missed your pickup for Week 2 (Aug. 10-14) you can pickup your device tomorrow, Aug. 15, from 8am - 1pm at the same designated location.

post_text:
SCS Family Forums provide an opportunity for all parents to gather, learn and share important information to support student learning and success in school. Our next Family Forum will focus on strategies and resources for students who receive support through special education, CLUE, 504 and English Language Learners. Live sessions will be led by experts from the Department of Exceptional Children and Health Services and the Department of English as a Second Language (ESL).

Join the session on August 22 at 10 a.m. and see the schedule now at http://www.scsk12.org/familyforum.

Please submit questions to familyforum@scsk12.org.

post_text:
We take our responsibility to provide a meaningful and high-quality learning experience for every student very seriously, and we will deliver on this promise whether our students are in school or at home. The virtual start of school will not be anything like the final quarter of last year. Every student will be provided with a digital device, and students will have live interaction with their teachers and peers every day as they follow the routine of a regular school day. We will continue to provide meals for students, and accommodations will be provided to support our students who receive special education services.

We remain determined to return to school as soon as it is safe to do so, but until then, our teachers will be ready to provide high quality instruction every day beginning August 31. Even virtually, we will #returnstronger.

More answers to frequently asked questions: bit.ly/3g3yoG0

Find more information and the latest updates at scsk12.org.

SCS is teaming up with iHeartMedia Memphis, Peppa Mouth of the South and 88.5FM The Voice of SCS to host a Virtual Block Party tomorrow from 6-7 PM! The event will stream live on the SCS Facebook and Twitter pages, and on 88.5FM.

Memphis’ own Rap superstar Moneybagg Yo will donate 10,000 facemasks to the faculty and students of SCS, and there will also be performances and more special guests. Don’t miss out! #SCSis901

Read more: ‪http://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1279‬

post_text:
LEARNING OPTION UPDATE

In an effort to better support our families, we are extending the period for parents to select a fall learning option. The deadline for parents to submit their choice will now be 11:59 p.m. on July 24.

In addition to allowing more time, we will be extending our call center hours (416-5300) to 7 a.m. - 7 p.m. Monday through Friday to assist families with questions about the options or accessing their PowerSchool account. We will also continue to update our FAQs so families have as much information as possible to make an informed choice for their child.

Find more information and a video Powerschool walkthrough at scsk12.org/learningoptions.

post_text:
The SCS School Board will be conducting a Special Called Meeting on Monday, July 13 at 4 p.m. As practiced at all SCS Board Business/Special Called Meetings, a Public Comment Submission period will open prior to the start of the meeting. Any citizen interested in providing public comment for this Special Called Meeting must submit their comment through email at BoardPublicComments@scsk12.org, between 2:00 p.m. and 3:15 p.m. on the day of the meeting.

Please include your name, home address, organization represented, if any, and subject of your comment in the email. Comments will not be read unless these items are included.

*Comments will be read in the order in which they are received, and in accordance with Board Policy 0000 School Board Meetings: IV Public Comment. Public comments will share the 30-minute time slot, in equal increments of time, not to exceed three (3) minutes each. In the event that a public comment is not read in its entirety within the individual allotted time, a full copy will be accessible to the Board.

Please include your name, home address, organization represented, if any, and subject of your comment in the email. Comments will not be read unless these items are included.

*Comments will be read in the order in which they are received, and in accordance with Board Policy 0000 School Board Meetings: IV Public Comment. Public comments will share the 30-minute time slot, in equal increments of time, not to exceed three (3) minutes each. post_text: Nearly 20,000 families have selected learning options for the fall semester this week, and we're assisting many more every day who continue to express thanks for having choices this upcoming school year. We're doing our best to answer as many questions as we can for families and employees and updating our S.A.F.E. Plan website regularly so everyone has access to the latest information. With that in mind, we're preparing for a Virtual Community Conversation on Monday, July 13, to discuss the S.A.F.E. plan in greater detail and address more questions from our community. Rounding out the week of big news, we announced plans for the Class of 2020 Virtual Graduation, which will be held on Saturday, July 18. Hear more in our latest weekly update video.

*Survey closing tomorrow

Now, more than ever, the ideas and support of those we serve is vital to continuing safe and effective education. We're working hard for our students, employees and the entire community, and your honest opinions about the quality of our leadership, schools and services will help drive us to be better.

The survey only takes about five minutes and is completely confidential. Every voice matters, so we appreciate your input to help strengthen education in the 901. Take the survey: http://www.scsk12.org/survey/

#SCSis901

post_text:
Peer Power is hosting a special creative writing contest for SCS students in grades 9-12! They will award three (3) $100 cash prizes to winning writing samples, which are guided by prompts purposed to include students in the conversation of what the 2020-2021 academic school year will look like. This Creative Writing Contest encourages storytelling and writing among high school students during COVID-19.

Students who submit to the Creative Writing Contest will receive free virtual support from Peer Power Success Coaches to improve their writing and grammar skills. Guest judges will review and score the writing samples and will ultimately determine the 3 winners.

To learn more about the Creative Writing Contest, visit peerpowerfoundation.org.

post_text:
Pending Board approval, SCS is considering adjusting the start and end dates for the 2020-21 school year. This is based on the Governor’s extended state of emergency declaration through August 29th due to rising cases of COVID-19. This proposal would not alter the structure or total number of instructional days (175) in the current calendar.

Please provide your feedback by JULY 10 in the survey below to help us in our decision: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/SCSCalendar20_ENG

************

Pendiente de la aprobación del Consejo Escolar, las Escuelas del Condado de Shelby está considerando ajustar las fechas del inicio y fin del año escolar 2020-21. Esto se basa en la declaración del estado de emergencia prolongado por el Gobernador hasta el 29 de agosto debido al aumento de los casos de COVID-19. Esta propuesta no alteraría la estructura ni el número total de días de instrucción (175) en el calendario actual.

Nos gustaría sus comentarios sobre dos opciones que estamos considerando (Abierto hasta el 10 de julio): https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/SCSCalendar20_SPAN

post_text: SCS Board Business Meeting - 6/30/20
text: SCS Board Business Meeting - 6/30/20

post_text:
As practiced at all SCS Board Business/Special Called Meetings, a Public Comment Submission period will open prior to the start of the meeting. Any citizen interested in providing public comment for this Business Meeting must submit their comment through email at BoardPublicComments@scsk12.org, between 4:00 p.m. and 5:15 p.m. on the day of the meeting.

Please include your name, home address, organization represented, if any, and subject of your comment in the email. Comments will not be read unless these items are included. Please see time limits below.

*Comments will be read in the order in which they are received, and in accordance with Board Policy 0000 School Board Meetings: IV Public Comment. Public comments will share the 30-minute time slot, in equal increments of time, not to exceed three (3) minutes each. In the event that a public comment is not read in its entirety within the individual allotted time, a full copy will be accessible to the Board.

post_text:
Join Keepers of 306, an action initiative of the National Civil Rights Museum, for a special live-streamed event on the value of voting as an attainable call to action for every Memphian and American. Listen and learn from local and national leaders in a virtual forum on National Civil Rights Museum's Facebook page or website, which will inspire our individual and collective commitment #tothepolls.

The forum will include a lesson on civics by CNN commentator Bakari Sellers, a historical context presentation by National Civil Rights Museum’s Dr. Noelle Trent, and a panel discussion on the “why” of voting, moderated by Tracie Potts NBC, featuring:

Dr. Thomas Parham, President of California State University, Dominguez Hills, human rights advocate

Rabbi Jonah Pesner, Director of the Religious Action Center of Reform Judaism in Washington, DC

Rev Earle J Fisher, Ph.D., pastor, college educator and community activist, #UPTheVote901, Memphis

State Senator Raumesh Akbari, Tennessee State Senate District 29, Memphis

post_text:
#Juneteenth is the oldest nationally celebrated commemoration of the ending of slavery in the United States. In addition to marking a date of major significance in American history, Juneteenth has always been both a day of remembrance and an opportunity to honor and celebrate Black culture.

Have a Proud and Happy Juneteenth!

Learn more about Juneteenth History at https://www.juneteenth.com/history.htm.

Juneteenth Reading List for grades K-12: https://coloursofus.com/10-childrens-books-celebrating-juneteenth/

Teaching Juneteenth: https://www.tolerance.org/magazine/teaching-juneteenth

Spaces are still available! Apply now at scsssla.org

The Virtual Summer Learning Academy is open to SCS students in grades K-5. There are 5,000 FREE spaces available for students to participate in the online enrichment program, which takes place July 6-31. Online applications are open through June 19. Laptops and hotspots will be available for families who do not have a home device or internet access while supplies last, and all students who complete the academy will receive a free backpack and school supplies for the upcoming 2020-21 school year!

post_text:
Bruce Elementary Principal Archie Moss received a special surprise for his school on national television last week during his appearance on the Ellen Show.

Principal Moss was a virtual guest on the Friday, June 12 episode where he discussed with Ellen the creative ways he remained engaged with his students and community throughout the school closure period and now during the recent national unrest. He also talked about the challenges his students and staff faced during this time. To help, Ellen and Box Tops for Education surprised Moss and Bruce Elementary School with a gift of $25,000.

Watch the segment and read more: http://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1256

Shelby County Schools is moving forward with the 1:1 digital device plan to provide devices to every student in the District.

“As part of our commitment to equity for all students, providing and supporting access to technology is vital to the learning process,” said Superintendent Dr. Joris M. Ray. “I’m thankful to our School Board and our Digital Advisory Committee for their valuable input as we worked to prepare a sustainable, cost-effective plan.”

Read more: http://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1257

Laptops and hotspots will be available for families who do not have a home device or internet access while supplies last, and all students who complete the academy will receive a free backpack and school supplies for the upcoming 2020-21 school year!

Apply now: https://scsssla.org/

post_text:
As we continue to explore all instructional options for the coming 2020-21 school year, we want to ensure families are equipped to support their students at home using the District's preferred distance learning platform. Microsoft Teams is a safe, free and easy-to-use virtual system that allows classes and groups to meet and work together online. It was used by many teachers in the spring to continue live instruction after schools closed. With the likelihood of implementing a combination of in-person and virtual instruction in the fall, this training designed especially for parents will help ensure our students are set up for successful learning.

Join us for an upcoming live Microsoft Teams Training Session! Register at http://www.scsk12.org/instructionalresources/teams

JUNE 15: 10- 11 a.m. | 1 - 2 p.m. | 6 - 7 p.m.

JULY 6: 10 - 11 a.m. | 1 - 2 p.m. | 6 - 7 p.m.

JULY 20: 10 - 11 a.m. | 1 - 2 p.m. | 6 - 7 p.m.

"We were born and raised in Nigeria. We take academic privileges seriously. We are involved in our children's learning, and we partner with our children's teachers." -The Olajide Family

post_text:
"My name is Mohamed Diallo and I'm a 10th grader at the Newcomer International Center (NIC). I like everything about school, especially the environment. I am from Senegal. One of the hardest things for me to overcome since coming to the States is adapting to the lifestyle. My family and I like to keep our culture alive. One part of the tradition I take seriously is my religion. I keep my traditions alive is by asking my parents or grandparents more about where I come from."

"What motivates me is that I don't forget where I am from. My mum inspires me the most, that's why I want to make her proud."

World Relief Memphis is highlighting stories like Mohamed's all month. Read more at worldreliefmemphis.org/blog. #immigrantheritagemonth #refugeeawareness #worldrefugeeday

SCS Newcomer International Center

Now, more than ever, the ideas and support of those we serve is vital to continuing safe and effective education. We're working hard for our students, employees and the entire community, and your honest opinions about the quality of our leadership, schools and services will help drive us to be better.

More than two dozen Shelby County Schools students received scholarships this year thanks to the Memphis Alumnae Chapter of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc..

Each year, MAC awards scholarships to Shelby County scholars in honor of members and lifelong educators Maggie McDowell and Lois Jefferson Gilder.

This year 26 of the 34 students who received scholarships attended SCS schools. Thank you for supporting our scholars!

post_text:
Stay up to date and tune in to tomorrow's Board Meeting through TV, radio, social media, or at scsk12.org/board. #SCSis901

***Public Comments Notice:

As practiced at all SCS Board Business Meetings, a Public Comment Submission period will open prior to the start of the meeting. Any citizen interested in providing public comment for the April Business Meeting must submit their comment through email at BoardPublicComments@scsk12.org, between 4:00 p.m. and 5:15 p.m. on Tuesday, May 26, 2020. *

Please include your name, home address, organization represented, if any, and subject of your comment in the email. Comments will not be read unless these items are included.

*Comments will be read in the order in which they are received, and in accordance with Board Policy 0000 School Board Meetings: IV Public Comment. Public comments will share the 30-minute time slot, in equal increments of time, not to exceed three (3) minutes each. In the event that a public comment is not read in its entirety within the individual allotted time, a full copy will be accessible to the Board.

post_text:
Holly Cooper teaches History at Central High School. A 22-year SCS teaching veteran, Cooper split her career between Kingsbury High and Central High spending 11 years at each. She teaches 10th grade and 11th grade History and AP History classes. Cooper takes advantage of Schoology, AP Classroom and email to ensure her students are ready for AP exams.

"These students deserve to have the best chance at success, and I am doing what I can to make sure they are prepared. They deserve every opportunity to get credit for all of their hard work this year. I am so proud of them!"

Read more: https://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1217

#LoveSCSTeachers

Do you want to take college courses during high school at no cost to you?

Join us for the CCTE Early College Virtual Interest Meetings on Wednesday, May 27th at 5:00 pm or Friday, May 29th at 12:00 pm to find out more about our Early College Program.

The Early College Program allows students to receive both high school and college credit simultaneously during the school day. The CCTE Early College Team will be available virtually to give you important information to get you started for the upcoming school year and to answer any questions you may have.

If you plan to attend, please complete the form below and choose one of the available dates, and will send you the link to join our virtual meeting.We look forward to seeing you there!!

RSVP: bit.ly/ecvirtual

School counselors have been contacting families of students who are eligible for the summer online program this week. The program allows students to make up failed courses and credits in order to advance to the next grade or graduate. K-8 students must be registered by *TOMORROW, May 22, and high school students must be registered by May 27.

*Get more info at scssummerschool.com.

post_text:
Our Class of 2020 Graduation website is here! Click on your high school's logo to view your commemorative program, and watch a special message from Supt. Joris M. Ray: http://www.scsk12.org/classof2020

To our 2020 graduates, we commend you on your incredible accomplishments along your academic journey with us. More importantly, we celebrate the amazing opportunities you're about to pursue and the life-changing goals we know you will achieve. You are SENIOR STRONG, and SCS and the 901 community couldn't be more proud of you - our future leaders!

This is only the first step in our salute to the Class of 2020. Please continue to check back for more updates throughout the summer as scheduled graduation activities for June and July are finalized, and get all the senior updates here: https://www.scsk12.org/coronavirusfacts/seniorupdates?PID=1671

Again, we congratulate you and thank you for representing SCS with pride. You are always a part of our family! Be sure to share your graduation excitement using #SCSSeniorStrong

post_text:
Cindy Geyer teaches Math at Germantown High School. An 18-year teaching veteran, Geyer has taught at GHS for the last 17 years. Geyer says her secret to ensuring her students keep learning during the school closure is her iPhone and email. Teaching through a consistent video lesson system, she has maintained 97% participation from her students during the closure.

"I want my students and their parents to know how very proud of them I have been through this whole process. They have worked very hard and I am impressed. I know they are great kids and I am not surprised by their efforts."

Read more and watch some of her videos: http://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1210 #LoveSCSTeachers

post_text:
Amid the unprecedented closure of schools due to COVID-19, the District has been working steadily to prepare a safe and flexible contingency plan that will be necessary to reopen schools and offices for the start of 2020-21.

• The District’s S.A.F.E. Planning Team has been meeting daily since the onset of the COVID-19 crisis. This cross-functional team is charged with assessing both short-term and long-term plans for academics and operational support functions while developing safe and comprehensive guidance for school-based and central office staff to manage
day-to-day priorities and eventually return to schools and offices.

• Superintendent Ray recently announced a Re-Entry Task Force comprised of key stakeholders with education, healthcare, faith-based and business expertise to advise and support the District in specific areas that will be critical to the reopening of schools.

Learn more about the Re-Entry Task Force: http://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1213

Learn more about the S.A.F.E. Contingency Plan: http://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1215

post_text:
Shelby County Schools will conduct an online summer program June 8 - July 16 for students in grades 1-12 who do not earn necessary credits or meet other requirements to advance to the next grade or graduate. The District will provide devices for enrolled students who do not have a computer at home.

Schools will be communicating directly with families whose children qualify for the summer online program the week of May 18. After being notified, students in grades 1-8 must be registered by May 22, and students in grades 9-12 must be registered by May 27.

Requirements and processes vary by grade level, so please review the appropriate sections below for your child's grade level carefully. If you have any questions, please contact your child's principal or teacher directly.

More Details: http://www.scsk12.org/coronavirusfacts/finalgrade
text:
Shelby County Schools will conduct an online summer program June 8 - July 16 for students in grades 1-12 who do not earn necessary credits or meet other requirements to advance to the next grade or graduate. The District will provide devices for enrolled students who do not have a computer at home.

Schools will be communicating directly with families whose children qualify for the summer online program the week of May 18. After being notified, students in grades 1-8 must be registered by May 22, and students in grades 9-12 must be registered by May 27.

Requirements and processes vary by grade level, so please review the appropriate sections below for your child's grade level carefully. If you have any questions, please contact your child's principal or teacher directly.

More Details: http://www.scsk12.org/coronavirusfacts/finalgrade

post_text:
Today's theme for Virtual Artsfest is Orff Music! The Orff Approach, named after German composer Carl Orff, is a developmental approach used in music education. It combines music, movement, drama, and speech into lessons that are similar to child's world of play. In this way, Orff is much more than music, it is a pathway to foundational skills and academic achievement for our young students. #SCSArtsMatter

Please enjoy this short teaser of some of the performances our wonderful students have put at their Side By Side Concerts with the amazing Memphis Symphony Orchestra and their All-City Performance at The Cannon Center for the Performing Arts!

Crump Elementary - https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLFMsstY630GyItyldKtsWCtMjnfw0z9m

Snowden Elementary - https://youtu.be/leKOfyEW9jc

post_text:
SCS Budget Proposal For 2020-21 School Year at the Shelby County Commission Meeting

We’re excited to present a balanced budget proposal for the 2020-21 school year to the Shelby County Commission this morning. We appreciate the leadership of our School Board and the input of our teachers, families and community stakeholders to help ensure we’re investing in key areas to strengthen outcomes for students: school & classroom supports, social & emotional support, early learning and academic transformation & innovation. We look forward to keeping everyone informed as we continue through this process.
text:
SCS Budget Proposal For 2020-21 School Year at the Shelby County Commission Meeting

We’re excited to present a balanced budget proposal for the 2020-21 school year to the Shelby County Commission this morning. We appreciate the leadership of our School Board and the input of our teachers, families and community stakeholders to help ensure we’re investing in key areas to strengthen outcomes for students: school & classroom supports, social & emotional support, early learning and academic transformation & innovation. We look forward to keeping everyone informed as we continue through this process.

post_text:
Enjoy a performance from earlier this year by SCS' very own award-winning Central HS Wind Enselmble at their Concert Assessment.

Assessment happens in the arts, but it is not driven by standardized test. Rather, it happens when young people strive toward excellence and display their work. We encourage each student (and adult!) to think of something they would like to improve on, and spend an hour focusing on getting better at it. Then, share your work using #SCSArtsMatter. Have fun!

Be sure to check out SCS Visual and Performing Arts for more arts content, and submit your art to scsk12.org/artsfest to be submitted in the Virtual Gallery next month!

post_text:
Christin Amos teaches Fourth Grade at Whitehaven Elementary STEM School. A five-year teaching veteran, this is her first year with SCS and Whitehaven Elementary. Amos meets with her students weekly via Google Classroom. She keeps them learning and having fun with STEM experiments and virtual field trips.

"When I found out we would not be returning after Spring Break, I knew I wanted to keep moving forward with my students so we could pick up right back up after we returned to school. My virtual classroom consists of Eureka Math, Science, ELA and STEM by way of Problem based learning."

Read more:http://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1204

#LoveSCSTeachers

post_text:
Jennifer Cordero is a 5th grade teacher at Campus School. She has worked for SCS for 17 years and has spent the last 11 at Campus School. Each Sunday, she emails parents the weekly assignments that are posted on her website, posts video lessons on YouTube and interacts with students on Facebook.

"For most students, and many adults, routine is necessary for mental and emotional well-being. Though virtual learning cannot replace the effect and experience of in-person teaching, it provides our children with a sense of normalcy. It relays the message that we will get through this if we keep moving forward, even if we are moving a little slower or in a different way."

Read more: http://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1202

#LoveSCSTeachers

post_text:
Welcome to another edition of My Virtual Classroom!

LaDeidra Donald teaches 2nd grade ESL at Treadwell Elementary School - SCS. While she has worked for SCS since 2005 as an assistant and substitute teacher, this is Donald’s first year as a full-time teacher. She makes a variety of videos in multiple virtual classrooms to keep her students engaged in education.

"It’s important to continue having class while we’re not in the physical building because I don’t want students to forget things we’ve worked hard on. I want them to remain engaged in their education as if they were still going every day. I think continuing to teach under these circumstances shows students how important their education is to me and how much I want them to succeed."

Read more: http://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1198

#LoveSCSteachers

post_text:
Although schools are closed due to the unprecedented COVID-19 pandemic, Shelby County Schools teachers remain dedicated to their students. Teachers across the District have taken their classrooms online to ensure students continue to learn and stay engaged with instruction.

Much like in school, each teacher’s classroom looks and works differently. In our new SCS Newsroom series “My Virtual Classroom,” we want to take you inside these online classes to show all the hard work our teachers are putting in each day to support students.

Our first entry features Stephanie McFadden of Snowden School! Stephanie teaches Kindergarten at Snowden School. A 21-year teaching veteran, this is her first year with SCS and Snowden. McFadden has been meeting with her students on Facebook every day since schools closed in March. Read more about her Virtual Classroom: http://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1186

post_text:
We are so excited to see our schools find innovative ways to highlight their senior successes! Earlier today, Whitehaven High School - SCS celebrated their first every Virtual Academic Signing Day! The Class of 2020 Tigers accumulated over $213 million in scholarships, including 50 “Million Dollar Scholars.”

Students also decorated their homes and gathered with their families to announce their college commitments. Senior Jordyn Westbrook accumulated the most money and will be headed to Fisk University with more $7 million in scholarships

Huge thanks to Peer Power, Board Member Shante Avant, Superintedent Dr. Joris M. Ray, keynote speaker Dr. John Marshall, Dr. Vincent Hunter and the entire Whitehaven family. We can’t wait to see more of these creative ways to celebrate our seniors! #SCSSeniorStrong

Watch the full broadcast - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0bnsuXqcFz0&feature=youtu.be&fbclid=IwAR0ShDW4mowQXC5B14HHp9oQvRtbTDnUd0BbN5swb55pQVRBL_U79uwmBrU

post_text:
Yesterday, SCS and its Project Graduation team implemented a digital device distribution for hundreds of students enrolled in Project Graduation. For the last five years, the program has offered credit recovery and accelerated graduation courses. Quarter 4 Project Graduation classes started Monday, April 27, and will extend through Friday, May 22.

“As a former alternative school director, I understand the need for layered support to keep students engaged and on track,” said Superintendent Dr. Joris M. Ray. “I’m extremely proud of the successful distribution of digital devices during this pandemic. We look forward to discussing the District’s next steps for improving digital access for all students.”

Learn more: http://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1191

post_text:
In preparation to review the District’s proposed budget for the 2020-21 school year in the coming weeks, School Board members are inviting parents, staff and community stakeholders to provide input on next year’s planned spending priorities.

The Board is collecting public input on the budget April 29 – May 6 by phone, (901) 416-6777, and email 2021BudgetComments@scsk12.org. Public input will be used to help finalize the District’s budget proposal, which will be presented to the Board in May. Learn more about the budget details at http://www.scsk12.org/news/?id=1158

Thank you for your feedback and support! #SCSis901

post_text:
Stay up to date and tune in to tomorrow's Board Meeting through TV, radio, social media, or at scsk12.org/board. #SCSis901

***Public Comments:

As practiced at all SCS Board Business Meetings, a Public Comment Submission period will open prior to the start of the meeting. Any citizen interested in providing public comment for the April Business Meeting must submit their comment through email at BoardPublicComments@scsk12.org, between 4:00 p.m. and 5:15 p.m. on Tuesday, April 28, 2020. *

Please include your name, home address, organization represented, if any, and subject of your comment in the email. Comments will not be read unless these items are included.

*Comments will be read in the order in which they are received, and in accordance with Board Policy 0000 School Board Meetings: IV Public Comment. Public comments will share the 30-minute time slot, in equal increments of time, not to exceed three (3) minutes each. In the event that a public comment is not read in its entirety within the individual allotted time, a full copy will be accessible to the Board.

post_text:
Today, Superintendent Dr. Joris M. Ray announced three key cabinet additions: Amity Schuyler as Chief of Strategy and Innovation, Kenneth M. Walker II as General Counsel and Chief Legal Officer (formerly interim), and Jerica Phillips as Chief of Communications.

“Schuyler, Walker, and Phillips all bring savvy leadership skills to the team as we change the landscape at Shelby County Schools,” Ray said. “I’m continuing to build a team of servant leaders who must be bold and courageous in ensuring effectiveness in the District.”

Read more: http://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1184

post_text:
To celebrate the 50th anniversary of Earth Day tomorrow, our Discovery Education partners have put together a virtual collection of 50 engaging activities that students, educators, and families can do to make a meaningful difference for our planet. 🌎 “50 Ways to Earth Day” includes live events, videos, challenges, Virtual Field Trips, and fun family activities from Discovery Education’s robust collection of Earth Day content, and features many of trusted partners.

Check it out! - https://www.discoveryeducation.com/learn/50-ways-to-earth-day/

Also, make sure to tune in to the Discovery Education Facebook page for a special message and video from Animal Planet’s “Extinct or Alive” host Forrest Galante, who will share with students what it’s like to be a wildlife biologist, why he’s so passionate about protecting animals, and some simple things they can do to make the world a better place for wildlife. The event start's tomorrow, April 22, at 9:00 am Central Time!
shared_text:
DISCOVERYEDUCATION.COM
50 Ways to Earth Day | Discovery Education

Check it out! - https://www.discoveryeducation.com/learn/50-ways-to-earth-day/

Also, make sure to tune in to the Discovery Education Facebook page for a special message and video from Animal Planet’s “Extinct or Alive” host Forrest Galante, who will share with students what it’s like to be a wildlife biologist, why he’s so passionate about protecting animals, and some simple things they can do to make the world a better place for wildlife. The event start's tomorrow, April 22, at 9:00 am Central Time!

post_text:
REMINDER: YMCA of Memphis & the Mid-South will continue to provide student meals this week. Starting today, North Frayser Community Center will serve as a COVID-19 testing site and will not be serving meals. Families are encouraged to pickup meals at Innovation Church (3925 Overton Crossing) instead.

Comprehensive learning guides covering lessons and activities for the rest of the school year are available at scsk12.org/instructionalresources. Due to an overwhelming response, the District is in the process of printing additional comprehensive learning guides/workbooks and a central location for distribution will be announced soon.

Comprehensive learning guides covering lessons and activities for the rest of the school year are available at scsk12.org/instructionalresources. Due to an overwhelming response, the District is in the process of printing additional comprehensive learning guides/workbooks and a central location for distribution will be announced soon.

As our District and community continue to cope with COVID-19, we recognize that many students and families are experiencing anxiety and a range of other emotions. Self-care and emotional self-regulation are especially important during these uncertain times, so the District is making it possible for students and parents to contact school social workers and counselors for assistance. See the flyer below for a variety of social emotional resources and learn more at scsk12.org/SELsupport.

Live Counselor Hotline (9a-4p, M-F): 901-416-8484

24-hour Informational Line (24/7): 901-416-2266

post_text: Starting next week, instead of releasing learning guides on a weekly basis, we will post and distribute a comprehensive learning packet that will include several weeks of lessons and activities. We will still be distributing packets at all of our meal sites on Monday and Tuesday, and the packets will be posted on our instructional resources website (scsk12.org/instructionalresources) for online viewing or downloads. We also want to be very clear that this approach in no way signals an extended closure of schools or an end to the school year -- this is simply a decision to streamline efforts and create a safer process for everyone involved. We've had nearly 500,000 visits to our instruction resources website over the past couple weeks, and over 31,000 printed guides have been picked up in person and we are extremely proud to provide these important resources for students. We are committed to supporting students and families every way we can for the rest of the year.

post_text:
The CARES Act provides one-time, relief funds to respond to the impact of school closures due to COVID-19. Districts and schools across the state are currently in the midst of responding to the immediate, urgent needs of students and families. The priority of Tennessee public education will remain ensuring our children are safe and healthy. Help the State determine the most impactful ways to support the response work already happening in schools and in future recovery efforts. Take the survey and give your feedback here: https://bit.ly/2x9YvtC

Additional comments can be sent to K12.Health@tn.gov.

This is an incredibly challenging time for everyone, and communities across Tennessee are coming together to find solutions. We appreciate your feedback and reflections on the best next steps to support children and schools in Tennessee.

post_text:
*Calling all SCS educators! Instructional Videos Needed!*

Access to quality instruction is always a primary goal of SCS. Response to this illness is uncharted territory for our entire community, but it does give us an opportunity extend learning outside classroom walls into the homes of our students. We are calling on our amazing SCS teachers to record 50 to 55 minute video lessons to help deliver instruction to our students. Teachers will record video lessons at home based on the identified standards in either ELA or Math. We will broadcast approved videos on C19, WMC, WKNO, and online for all SCS families.

Find the step-by-step guide to create and submit videos here: http://www.scsk12.org/instructionalresources/video.php#/

post_text: These past couple of weeks have presented challenges we've never seen at Shelby County Schools or anywhere in our city. Through it all, we continue to see inspiring examples of resilience, empathy and understanding by our students, families and staff. We may not know how long this will last, and we may not know what will happen next. But, what we do know - no matter what - is that SCS is 901, and we are committed to doing everything in our power to keep supporting our community.

post_text:
FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE: The TN Dept. of Human Services is helping families impacted by COVID-19. Families can apply online for up to 2 months of emergency cash assistance if you were employed as of 3/11/20 and lost employment or at least 50% of income due to the pandemic.

Details: https://tn.gov/humanservices/news/2020/3/25/financial-aid-available-for-certain-families-that-lost-employment-due-to-covid-19.html
text:
FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE: The TN Dept. of Human Services is helping families impacted by COVID-19. Families can apply online for up to 2 months of emergency cash assistance if you were employed as of 3/11/20 and lost employment or at least 50% of income due to the pandemic.

Details: https://tn.gov/humanservices/news/2020/3/25/financial-aid-available-for-certain-families-that-lost-employment-due-to-covid-19.html

shared_text:
The College Board
March 24 at 12:09 PM ·

Daily optional lessons for most AP courses will begin tomorrow on YouTube. http://spr.ly/61811Q5iL. More coming soon.

Lessons will be delivered by AP teachers from across the country and can be used alongside work teachers are giving their students. Teachers are welcome to join!

The first weeks will focus on the end of the course, key topics that colleges expect students to learn but won’t be on exams. Teachers will also provide exam prep each day. As exams approach, teachers will focus primarily on review of concepts/skills that could appear on exams.

Some lessons being taught this week:
#APUSH: 8.3 The Red Scare
#APBio: 7.2 Natural Selection
#APPsych: 8.1 Introduction to Psychological Disorders

See more topics being covered this week and the full course schedule here: http://spr.ly/61821Q5i0.

post_text:
Thanks to a tremendous outpouring of support from local and state elected officials, as well as community organizations and businesses, thousands of students will be able to receive FREE meals every day while schools are closed. Beginning Monday, March 23, the YMCA of Memphis & the Mid-South will be taking over meal distribution at all sites previously designated for SCS meals. The YMCA is providing all of the food and coordinating distribution with its own staff members. The YMCA is a valued partner, and the District is extremely appreciative for this support in such a time of urgent need. As originally planned, meals will be available M-F while schools are closed (through April 3), 11 a.m. - 1 p.m., for all children 18 and under. The child must be present to receive a meal.

Additionally, the Mid-South Food Bank is making meals available for students at all of its mobile food pantries in the Memphis area, and several businesses are providing FREE or discounted student meals. View all meal pickup sites and details here - http://www.scsk12.org/coronavirusfacts/

post_text:
We are committed to providing instructional support to our students during this school closure period. Our new website dedicated to instructional supports includes grade-level specific learning guides along with online learning tools like iReady, Edgenuity, ACT, and Kaplan. We also understand that some families may not have a device or internet access, so we will have printed copies of the learning guides next week on Monday and Tuesday at the meal distributions sites. **We want to stress that the paper guides are reserved for those families who do not have online access**

We encourage the rest of our families to download the academic guides on our website at www.scsk12.org/instructionalresources.

Contributions to our COVID-19 Relief Fund to help bridge the digital divide for our families can be made here:
http://www.scsk12.org/instructionalresources/cc?PID=1641

post_text:
This evening, Superintendent Ray announced an extension of the current school and District closure until at least Monday, April 6. This comes after Governor Lee and the TN Dept. of Education shared guidance to extend closures until Tuesday, March 31. However, rather than have staff and students return mid-week, we are planning at this time for a return date of no earlier than Monday, April 6.

Additionally, SCS is aware of the new CDC recommendations to consider school closures for up to eight weeks. That said, our District leaders are acting cautiously and responsibly to mitigate all risks during the current health crisis, and will continue to evaluate all matters as we approach the planned April 6 return date.

Stay up to date on all developments by following our Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram and visiting www.scsk12.org/coronavirusfacts.

post_text:
SCS is committed to addressing food insecurity and ensuring that all students continue to receive meals while the District is closed. The District has developed a food distribution strategy that minimizes risk for students and families who may pick up meals. Meals will be provided at 20 sites across the county March 23-27 between the hours of 11 a.m. and 1 p.m. each day. Meals will be served to children under the age of 18, and the child must be present to receive a meal.

Find more information at www.scsk12.org/coronavirusfacts

post_text:
The WIDA ACCESS for English Language Learners testing window will continue until April 3. Learn more about how this test is used to help ESL students and teachers.

**What does WIDA measure?
It measures English Language Proficiency, broken down into four domains- reading, writing, speaking, and listening. Not only does it measure social language, but it also measures the content specific language needed for academic success.

**How will the scores be used?
Parents can use the scores to advocate for their child, teachers can use scores to plan instruction and assessments, and the district can use the scores to evaluate language support programs.

**Parent Handouts

English: https://wida.wisc.edu/sites/default/files/resource/ACCESS-Parent-Handout-English.pdf

Spanish: https://wida.wisc.edu/sites/default/files/resource/ACCESS-Parent-Handout-Spanish.pdf

#widabest

Many children with (and without) learning difficulties need specific study strategies. They may not know what to study or how to approach studying, may have difficulty remembering the information, or may have trouble expressing what they know (especially in essays). GreatSchools.org has provided study strategies and examples to maximize your student's studying potential. Learn all about them here: https://www.greatschools.org/gk/articles/study-and-test-taking-strategies-for-kids-with-learning-difficulties/

#SCSisTNReady

post_text:
Don't forget to join us tonight at The Arcade Restaurant for our #BlackHistoryMonth Read-In!

In partnership with The Arcade Restaurant, Memphis' Oldest Cafe, the SCS Family and Community Engagement team will host a family reading night Monday, February 24 from 5 - 7 p.m. This program will be submitted to the National Council of Teachers of English’s "African American Read-In." Students and families will receive book donations to add to students’ at home libraries (e.g., "Sit-In: How Four Friends Stood Up by aSitting Down" and "Freedom on the Menu: The Greensboro Sit-Ins"). #Commit2Literacy

Shelby County Schools Office of Coordinated School Health has prepared information and resources for families that offer recommendations for nutrition, hydration, sleep, and physical activity to ensure our student’s academic success on their #TNReady state exams. Let’s start now! These tips can be followed routinely leading up to testing. Along with adequate academic, mental, social and emotional preparation for testing, we allow for improved health and academic achievement for all SCS students. Healthy Students Are Ready Learners! #SCSisTNReady.

Learn more:http://www.scsk12.org/tnready/files/2016/TN%20Ready%20Toolkit.pdf?PID=1178

post_text:
Applications for the annual Step Ahead Scholarship are open from now until April 3! Get all the information and download the application here: https://www.astepaheadfoundation.org/sites/540/uploaded/files/20202021_A_Step_Ahead_Scholarship_Application.pdf

The Step Ahead Scholarship program is a collaborative effort of A Step Ahead Foundation and Girls Inc. of Memphis to support their commitment to encouraging the educational advancement and leadership development of young women in the greater Memphis community. Multiple scholarships of at least $2,000 will be awarded from a $100,000 fund.

***Eligibility

- Candidates must be female and between the ages of 17 and 35.
- Candidates must have been a resident of Shelby County for a period of at least 2 years.
- Candidates must have applied to an accredited institution of secondary education at the time of
application. This includes colleges and universities, as well as technical and vocational schools.

Did you know the ELA portion of the TNReady test will feature a writing prompt? In grade 3, students will be asked to write one paragraph per response. In grades 4 through 8, the length of the response requested will be longer.

Over this long holiday weekend, make sure to use the at-home practice test with your student to ensure they get some writing practice! Together, School + Parents + Community = #SCSisTNReady.

Find the practice tests and more resources at www.scsk12.org/tnready

post_text: Larose Elementary and Ida B. Wells Academy will dismiss early at 11:45am today due to a power outage. Fallen tree limbs fell on the power lines near our school, and MLGW will not be able to complete the repairs quickly enough to continue our school day. We are very sorry for this unexpected inconvenience, however we are making this decision in the best interests of our students and staff. Normal dismissal procedures will be followed and students will be served lunch before dismissal.

post_text:
On Feb. 26, in honor of #BlackHistoryMonth, The Brooks Museum will host a special discussion around Just Mercy, the #1 The New York Times best-selling novel and major motion picture starring Michael B. Jordan and Jamie Foxx. The session will tackle issues such as mass incarceration, criminal justice reform, the death penalty, mental health, and other topics raised in the book.

The event is free and open to the public. Students, parents, and teachers are all invited to participate!

post_text:
Did you know that TNReady is a timed state test that measures student’s progress and growth in multiple subjects? The Spring 2020 #TNReady test will consist of:

Grades 3 – 5: 4 subparts of English, 3 subparts of Math, 1 subpart of science

Grades 6 – 8: 4 subparts of English, 3 subparts of Math, 1 subpart of science, 2 subparts of social studies

To learn more about the test subjects and time limits by grade, click here: https://www.tn.gov/content/dam/tn/education/testing/assessment_times_2019-20.pdf

#SCSisTNready

post_text:
Meet Your District 1 Board Member, Michelle Robinson McKissack!

Already an engaged parent, Mrs. McKissack joined the Board to elevate her service and impact for all Shelby County students. A product of White Station High School and former CLUE student herself, she is especially proud of her work on Universal Screening for CLUE to open new doors for children and increase equity in our District.

Outside of her service to SCS, she has a passion for the outdoors and travel, and loves to explore with her family, from her own neighborhood to the Mississippi River to Europe!

She is greatly inspired by her mother, who raised five children and discovered a passion for composing classical choral music at an age when most would retire.

"She is a woman of great faith and someone I want to emulate in every way."

#MySCSBoard

post_text:
Meet your District 3 Board Member, Stephanie Love! ❤️

A fixture in her community, Ms. Love passionately represents her District 3 family, and is greatly inspired and motivated by her own family:

"Those who inspire me are my oldest sister who beat cancer in 2019, my children, also known as “my 4 piece - hold the salt please,” and my adorable grandson, also known as my little nugget! Most of all, my father and late mother are my inspiration. My mother spent her entire life helping others with a smile. Even though she is no longer with us, her spirit and all she has taught me affords me the perfect opportunity to continue her legacy. "

Thank you, Ms. Love, for your constant service to our students, families, and educators. #MySCSBoard

post_text:
Get to know your District 7 Board Member and Board Chair, Miska Clay Bibbs!

Ms. Bibbs chose to become a Board member to push for student equity and make sure parent voices are always heard, and she is especially proud of the 2 brand-new schools in her community -- Parkway Village Elementary - SCS and New Alcy Elementary.

While her passion for education is evident, what you may not know is that she is also a DJ! - "I love music and love being able to use music as a form of expression. So many different voices can stand out and be heard through music."

Her main inspiration comes from family and motivates her daily:

"My grandparents inspired me the most by teaching me the importance of giving of oneself in order to prosper. My mother and aunts have been an amazing support system for me. They taught me how to be strong and lead with grace."

#MySCSBoard Miska Clay Bibbs

post_text:
Meet your District 6 Board Member, Shante Avant!

Ms. Avant joined the Board to be an advocate for all children to have choices to meet their academic needs, and is especially proud of the work she has done in the Whitehaven Empowerment Zone, Career and Technical Education, and fighting against generational poverty.

Outside of her duties, she enjoys reading and traveling to experience something new and learn every day. She is inspired by her mother and sister.

"My mother and sister inspire me the most. They are two of the strongest people I know mentally and spiritually. My mother is giving, kind, and wise. My sister is generous, smart, and ALWAYS has my back."

#MySCSBoard

post_text:
Imagine if every student could attend a school with modern facilities, a wide array of creative and competitive programs, robust technology, and resources to accelerate learning and strong social-emotional supports to help address and overcome barriers to success. It will require transformational VISION and ACTION, and that means ALL options must be considered for our students. It’s time to reimagine the way we deliver education in the 901.

Tune in live to learn more on SCS Facebook, Twitter, and all Voice of SCS Platforms on Thursday, Jan. 30 at 9AM, and watch the full broadcast any time after on this page. #SCSis901 #Reimagining901

We are so honored and humbled by the Plough Foundation’s gift of ONE MILLION dollars to our 11 Continuous Improvement Zone Schools. These formerly underperforming schools have made outstanding progress since their graduation from the iZone, and we are ensuring that this achievement and growth continues with additional support and resources. We are so proud to work with such prestigious organizations like The Plough Foundation to give the best to our students and staff. Thank you! #SCSis901

Learn more about the SCS Innovation Zone(iZone) schools: http://www.scsk12.org/izone/

Learn more about the Continuous Improvement Zone: tinyurl.com/wx5x56u

post_text: Today was a special day at Bruce Elementary School, as the community honored the 3 brave first graders who integrate the school for the first time. Harry Williams, Dwania Kyles, and Menelik Fombi, known as the “Bruce 3”, were immortalized at the school, as the walls were covered with beautiful reminders of the historic occasion. A huge 901 thank you to artist Jamond Bullock and ServiceMaster for making this inspiration possible! 💙 #FreedomForward #SCSis901

post_text:
Since 1970, SCS has operated its gifted and talented program known as C.L.U.E. (Creative Learning in a Unique Environment). The C.L.U.E. program provides Pre-K through 12th grade students with enriched learning experiences that develop leadership abilities, creativity, cooperative learning, and self-examination skills. The program currently serves over 3,500 SCS students - and now it is expanding by putting equity in action in its 50th anniversary year!

We have implemented a game-changing process for how students are chosen for further C.L.U.E. testing. Rather than relying only on adult recommendation, we have introduced the Universal Screener Assessment, allowing the student's own academic performance to determine their eligibility. This has resulted over 4,000 more students being assessed for C.L.U.E, 602 brand new C.L.U.E. students, and 13 new C.L.U.E. Centers. We are committed to the mission of giving EVERY student the opportunity to succeed and excel! #SCSis901

post_text:
As #BlackHistoryMonth approaches, we are excited to share opportunities both inside and outside our schools to engage our 901 students in meaningful and important dialogue. University of Tennessee Health Science Center Student National Medical Association (SNMA) is hosting a free event on February 8 for students in grades 5-12. This event is dedicated to helping students achieve success while learning how to interact with people in a diverse environment. Activities include goals and professionalism, clinical medical skills, and cultural competency. Breakfast and lunch provided!

Register here: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeIOJQFnlp7kjf-RTmjUdwQ52Y2j4AD4wAEEr9rsqxcQuv4dw/viewform?fbclid=IwAR0oD9rkijubebZxMpULeVdsMPPAzl5BfTKZESUF7kRjYRU9usJl2Jd5GuY

The Student National Medical Association (SNMA) is committed to supporting current and future underrepresented minority medical students, addressing the needs of underserved communities, and increasing the number of clinically excellent, culturally competent and socially conscious physicians.

post_text:
Looking for a way to celebrate MLK Weekend in a fun family environment? New Ballet Ensemble and School is providing a free dance and arts event for our families! #SCSis901
-------------------
Celebrate Martin Luther King Jr’s legacy with a day of dance and service at New Ballet’s 3rd Annual MLK Arts Unite! This event is FREE and open to the public, and will include arts workshops in dance and music, including Flamenco, West African, and Memphis Jookin, and participants will have an opportunity to perform what they’ve learned! There will also be a Volunteer Mentor Information Session during the event for those interested in becoming a mentor at New Ballet.

We will also be collecting donations of winter items for Mariposas Collective. Please bring coats, scarves, gloves, hats, and other items that will bring comfort and warmth during the winter season! Just Wraps Memphis will be on site serving food, and MEMPopS will be serving up sweet treats!

We are BEYOND proud to celebrate another Milken Family Foundation Educator Award winner in our Disitrict - Mr. Nathan Kirsch of Whitehaven High School - SCS! A national award only given to a handful of the 3 Million+ teachers in the US, this honor also includes a $25K prize! Thank you and congrats, Mr. Kirsch! Your heart, talent, and dedication to our students is making a BIG impact! 🌟 Read more about his inspiring work here: https://www.milkeneducatorawards.org/newsroom/press-releases/view/tn-math-teacher-nathan-kirsch-receives-milken-educator-25000

#SCSis901 #Respectthehaven #MilkenAward

post_text:
During the month of January, SCS will host Family Data Nights to bring information directly to parents about the assessments (tests) we give throughout the school year (first meeting tomorrow at BTW High!) Each school will provide parents with an overview of each assessment, information on student progress, guidance on how to read assessment data reports, and recommendations on how to help students at home. Parents of Kindergarten through 2nd grade students will also have the opportunity to review Criteria for Success for achieving the 3rd Grade Commitment and learn about tracking progress using the the recent report card updates.

Check your school’s scheduled dates and join us: http://www.scsk12.org/academic/datanight#?PID=1590

post_text:
WELCOME TO THE BRAND NEW PARKWAY VILLAGE ELEMENTARY!

We are so excited to unveil this state-of-the-art 21st Century School as the new home for our Goodlett and Knight Road Elementary families. From floor to ceiling, this school has been designed with one purpose in mind - providing the most productive, modern, and safe environment in which our future leaders will thrive. Take a look around! #SCSis901 #Reimagining901

Follow Parkway Village Elementary - SCS to stay up to date on the all the exciting PVE news in their inaugural semester!

The City of Memphis MPLOY program provides paid internships ($1,680) over the summer for students to gain valuable work experience before graduation! Make sure to apply for next summer's program by Dec. 31! *** Be sure to list "CCTE" for question 18 so they know you are an SCS Student!***

Learn more and apply at http://www.cityofmemphisyouth.org/index.html

shared_text:
Shelby County Schools - SCS
December 16, 2019 at 10:55 AM ·

‪UPDATE: 416-5300 is back up and operating normally. ‬

Our main line (901-416-5300) is current experiencing some technical issues. We apologize for the inconvenience and are working on restoring the line now. Thank you for your patience and we will post updates as soon as it is back up!

post_text:
The Memphis Tigers Football team has been busy preparing for their big matchup in Texas at the Cotton Bowl Classic, but not too busy to support SCS Students and #Commit2Literacy! In partnership with Crye-Leike, our hometown team will be supplying every student at Gardenview Elementary with gifts, including the gift of literacy, as they read to every classroom in the school! We are so proud to have had such amazing support from University of Memphis this year and look forward to continuing our work of empowering the 901 together.

#SCSis901 #GoTigersGo #BeatPennState Crye-Leike Real Estate Services 866.310.3102

SCS takes pride in serving our families, students and community. We’ve created the 5-Star Service Award to recognize hard-working employees in our schools across the District who go above and beyond to provide outstanding customer service. #SCSis901 #5StarService

post_text: These are the faces of our young readers and future leaders - and the reason why we do what we do! Thank you so much to everyone who supported Read Around the Christmas Tree today and to those who support SCS every day. ❤️ #Commit2Literacy #SCSis901
text: These are the faces of our young readers and future leaders - and the reason why we do what we do! Thank you so much to everyone who supported Read Around the Christmas Tree today and to those who support SCS every day. ❤️ #Commit2Literacy #SCSis901

post_text: 1,500 readers, 1,500 children! Thank you so much to everyone who came out to give our young readers the gift of a story and books to take home, and a big thanks to our wonderful hosts at New Direction Christian Church! 💖🎄📖 We got our holiday wish and a saw the 901 #Commit2Literacy. Teachers, parents, students, District officials, School Board Members, community leaders, elected officials, nonprofit partners, local and international businesses, first responders (special shout out to Shelby County Sheriff's Office!), members of our armed forces, and so many more showed their dedication to our students. THANK YOU! #SCSis901

Teachers, parents, students, District officials, School Board Members, community leaders, elected officials, nonprofit partners, local and international businesses, first responders (special shout out to Shelby County Sheriff's Office!), members of our armed forces, and so many more showed their dedication to our students. post_text:
1,500 readers, 1,500 children! Thank you so much to everyone who came out to give our young readers the gift of a story and books to take home, and to our wonderful hosts at New Direction Christian Church! 💖🎄📖 We had teachers, fellow students, District officials, School Board Members, local and international businesses, community leaders, elected officials, first responders, members of our military - our largest an most diverse group of volunteers ever! We are overjoyed that we got our holiday wish fulfilled and a saw the 901 #Commit2Literacy!

#SCSis901 SCS Family and Community Engagement

post_text: As our SCS 8th Graders prepare to leap from Middle to High School, they have a lot of decisions to make concerning their academic and professional future. Our Counseling Department and Division of COllege, Career, and Technical Education (CCTE) brought all of our 8th graders to one location where they could meet representatives from all of our schools, and even outside programs, to learn what options are available to them in the next four years. It's never too soon to envision your unique #ReadyGrad Path! #SCSis901

post_text:
The SCS Early College Program gives students an opportunity to experience college courses on a college campus to give them the experience and knowledge to excel in their first semester after high school as a #ReadyGrad This month we would like to highlight two exceptional students and their experiences at Southwest Tennessee Community College.

Ashaunte Banks, a Craigmont High School student, is a conscientious and hard-working student. She demonstrates a rare ability in writing and a consistent willingness to learn and improve. Her kind disposition and work ethic make her a role model for those around her.

R'Eonna Stewart, a Mitchell High School student, has exemplified outstanding academic performance throughout the semester, maintaining a 98 average. Moreover, her time management skills, work ethic, and positive energy contribute to a productive classroom atmosphere.

Learn more about our Early College Program at http://www.scsk12.org/ccte/#/learning #SCSis901

post_text:
An #SCSis901 Story on: Heart

Deirdre McClellan exemplifies heart as a school psychologist because she has brought unparalleled passion to her job each day for the last 32 years.

Deirdre knew at early age in her life that she wanted to work with preschool age children and eventually children suspected of having autism as well. Upon graduating from Memphis State University, she immediately began working as a school psychologist. She now works full time at the Colonial Hearing, Speech, and Vision Center where she evaluates preschool age children, using her wonderful gift of empathy to reassure parents and bring out the unique qualities in her students. Also a leader in our community in assessment of autism, Deirdre was among the first in west Tennessee to receive specialized training at Vanderbilt University. #SPAW2019

Read more about Deirdre: http://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1085

post_text:
An #SCSis901 story on: Innovation

Nichol Pritchard is proud to be a school psychologist serving Snowden, Manassas High School, and Believe Academy. She works closely with general and special education teams in her schools to identify needs for her students.

Nichol exemplifies innovation by being one of only a few SCS school psychologists certified in Crisis Prevention Intervention instructor helping others in the district to use de-escalation techniques with students. She saw a need in one of her own schools and helped to bring cutting-edge training teachers, administrators, and security officers to recognize the emotional well-being of the students they work with and try new de-escalation techniques schoolwide. #SCSis901 #SPAW2019

Learn more about Nichol:
http://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1080

post_text:
The next Secure the Chalk event is coming up next Thursday, Nov. 21st! It is open to all educators in Shelby County and surrounding areas.

The underrepresentation of African American men in education not only negatively affects students of color, but all students who enter the classroom. The Secure the Chalk Educator Fellowship is a professional membership and activist organization dedicated to advancing the recruitment, development and retention of Black male educators in schools throughout Greater Memphis Area. #OurBoysNeedUs

Learn more at http://www.scsk12.org/ourboys/

post_text:
An SCS is 901 Story on: Soul

Working as a school psychologist for almost twenty years, Julia Huckabee is the soul of her department. She currently serves White Station High, Cordova High, Northeast Prep, Northwest Prep, and the Adolescent Parenting Program.

“I feel like my mental health experience is helpful to me in my current position both in terms of assessment and communication skills,” said Julia. “It also helps me 'think outside the box' in terms of problem resolution and ways to support the students and faculty in my schools.”

Get to know more about Julia:
http://www.scsk12.org/newsroom/#/article/1079 #SCSis901

post_text:
SCS will be dismissing Kingsbury Middle and High school at 10:30am due to a gas leak in the building. Unfortunately, repairs cannot be made soon enough to allow the school day to continue. We apologize for the sudden inconvenience, but we believe it is in the best interest of students to dismiss early today. All students will be fed lunch before they leave today, and both schools will follow normal dismissal procedures. Staff will remain on campus until all students are safely dismissed. There is no impact to Kingsbury Elementary school as a result of the gas leak. The elementary school day will continue as regularly scheduled. Only Kingsbury Middle and High school will be dismissing at 10:30am.

Kingsbury High School Kingsbury Middle School. TN

There is no impact to Kingsbury Elementary school as a result of the gas leak. The elementary school day will continue as regularly scheduled. Only Kingsbury Middle and High school will be dismissing at 10:30am.
